RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH: Professor Adjunto A do Departamento de Engenharia de Estruturas da Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais (UFMG), possui doutorado em Engenharia de Estruturas pela UFMG, mestrado em Engenharia Civil pela Università degli Studi di Firenze (Itália), e graduação em Engenharia Civil pela Università degli Studi di Firenze (Itália). É membro da equipe de desenvolvedores do software livre INSANE (INteractive Structural ANalysis Environment) e pesquisador dos Grupos de Pesquisa da UFMG intitulados "Simulação Numérica e Computacional na Mecânica dos Sólidos e das Estruturas" e "Estruturas de Concreto Armado e Protendido". Atua nas áreas de pesquisa da mecânica computacional e mecânica dos sólidos, com foco em métodos meshfree, análise fisicamente e geometricamente não-linear, continuos generalizados e modelagem de materiais parcialmente frágeis.
RESUMO-CV.TEXTO-RESUMO-CV-RH-EN: Pre-tenured faculty at the Structural Engineering Departement of the Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais (UFMG, Brazil), with PhD in Structural Engineering by the UFMG, and master?s degree and bachelor?s degree in Civil Engineering by the Università degli Studi di Firenze (Italy). Member of the development team of the open-source Java software INSANE (INteractive Structural ANalysis Environment) and researcher for the UFMG research groups named "Numerical and Computational Simulation in Solids and Structural Mechanics" and "Reinforced and Prestressed Concrete Structures". Works in the research field of computational mechanics and solid mechanics, with focus on meshfree methods, physically and geometrically nonlinear analysis, generalized continua, and modelling of quasi-brittle media.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Development of meshfree methods for structural analysis
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Most engineering applications rely on the finite element method (FEM) for their computational aspects. Such a tool has a long history both in the academic and applied fields, and is available in a number of proprietary and open-source codes for structural analysis. However, it shows some limitations in certain applications, especially when nonlinear (physically and/or geometrically) problems are considered. A number of more advanced computational tools have been available in the literature for a long time, and more recently are also been included in proprietary software for structural analysis. Among them, the family of meshfree methods has gained a growing interest in the academic community, and the first commercial codes based on this strategy begin to appear. The present project aims to investigate the application and adaptation of existent meshfree methods to different fields of structural engineering, including static and dynamic problems, with both physical and geometrical nonlinearities. The project also aim to conceive new meshfree methods and to propose improvements to existing ones.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Most engineering applications rely on the finite element method (FEM) for their computational aspects. Such a tool has a long history both in the academic and applied fields, and is available in a number of proprietary and open-source codes for structural analysis. However, it shows some limitations in certain applications, especially when nonlinear (physically and/or geometrically) problems are considered. A number of more advanced computational tools have been available in the literature for a long time, and more recently are also been included in proprietary software for structural analysis. Among them, the family of meshfree methods has gained a growing interest in the academic community, and the first commercial codes based on this strategy begin to appear. The present project aims to investigate the application and adaptation of existent meshfree methods to different fields of structural engineering, including static and dynamic problems, with both physical and geometrical nonlinearities. The project also aim to conceive new meshfree methods and to propose improvements to existing ones.
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: Development of meshfree methods for structural analysis

FINANCIADOR-DO-PROJETO.NOME-INSTITUICAO: Conselho Nacional de Desenvolvimento Científico e Tecnológico

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Generalized continua for the nonlinear modelling of media with complex microstructure
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: A large number of materials which are of interest in various engineering applications are characterized by a nonlinear (physically and/or geometrically) behaviour and present a complex microstructure, which exert a significant influence on the macrostructural behaviour. Among them there are, for example, concrete, rocks, granular materials, composites, biological materials (like the different kinds of bones) and metamaterial. Such materials are often used in strategic applications, where their possibly nonlinear behaviour must be evaluated with great precision. The standard approach to continuum mechanics, based on the Cauchy continuum, presents some limitations when used to model the aforementioned materials, which in turns benefit from the use of the so-called generalized continuum theories. The present project aims to investigate the use of generalized continuum theories for the nonlinear modelling of media with complex microstructure, both by improving existing models and proposing new ones. Furthermore, the combination of such theories with different computational strategies will be considered. For a given material the developed tools should allow to (i) predict, in a reliable way, its nonlinear behaviour and degrading phenomena, (ii) point out the microstructural effect capable to significantly influence the macrostructural behaviour, and (iii) guarantee a certain reliability of the computational results.
